node.title: A Quiet Studio With a Home-Court Advantage
node.description: Tim Burns, who trains basketball players, including N.B.A. pros, found a studio in Brooklyn for $3,150. His favorite amenity: the basketball court.

node.title: Why Republicans Won in a New York County Where Democrats Outnumber Them
node.description: Voters readily ousted Democrats in Nassau County on Long Island, electing Republicans down the ballot.

node.title: When the Taliban Are in Your Bedroom
node.description: As armed Taliban inspected the New York Times bureau in Kabul, they were escorted by a journalist who used to be a U.S. Marine. The photo of him in uniform was plain for all to see, and ponder.

node.title: In Romania, Hard-Hit by Covid, Doctors Fight Vaccine Refusal
node.description: An anti-vaccine clarion call by leading religious figures, echoed by prominent politicians and social media, helps explain why Romania now has the world’s highest Covid death rate.

node.title: New Zealand’s biggest city will ease lockdown restrictions.
node.description: The lifting of rules comes as the country records some of its highest daily case numbers since the pandemic began.

node.title: The U.S. allows vaccinated international travelers in and bars unvaccinated travelers from abroad.
node.description: The change ends more than 18 months of restrictions that left families separated from loved ones and cost the global travel industry hundreds of billions of dollars.

node.title: Jill Biden and surgeon eneral kick off kids vaccination campaign
node.description: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommended Pfizer's pediatric vaccine just last week, on November 2.

node.title: Inside a Volcanic Ritual on the Indonesian Island of Java
node.description: During the Hindu ceremony of Yadnya Kasada, the Tenggerese people toss offerings — food, money, flowers, livestock — into the hazy crater of Mount Bromo.

node.title: Police Officer Stabbed on French Riviera, Authorities Say
node.description: Gérald Darmanin, France’s interior minister, said an unidentified assailant had stabbed an officer in Cannes. The motive for the attack was not immediately clear.

node.title: As Tensions Rose, U.S. Intelligence Spotted Election Meddling by China, Russia, Iran
node.description: In this daily series, Newsweek explores the steps that led to the January 6 Capitol Riot.

node.title: Concertgoers sue over deadly crowd surge at Astroworld music fest
node.description: Rappers Travis Scott and Drake, as well as Live Nation and others are among the defendants in at least three suits. The "mass casualty incident" occurred during Scott's performance on Friday night, authorities said.

node.title: 'Tsunami' of Gravitational Waves From Violent Cosmic Events Detected
node.description: A member of the team who made the detection said the work represents a "major leap forward in our quest to unlock the secrets of the Universe's evolution."

node.title: Joe Biden's Approval Rating Remains Dismal, Kamala Harris' Is Even Worse
node.description: The president's approval rating is only just above an all-time low, with Harris' just at 28 percent, according to USA Today-Suffolk University poll.

node.title: An Urban Problem: Rats on the Rise
node.description: The rodent population has surged in the pandemic.

node.title: Murder trial begins for WA father who allegedly inflicted 'head to foot' injuries on baby boy
node.description: A father on trial for murder allegedly inflicted "head to foot" injuries on his baby son — either by "vigorously" shaking or through other violent behaviour — towards the seven-month-old boy, the Supreme Court of WA hears.

node.title: Jim Acosta's 'Stop the Squeal' Message to Republicans Goes Viral
node.description: The CNN anchor noted that there was a "peaceful transfer of power" after Republican Glenn Youngkin won Virginia's race for governor.

node.title: Labor leader wore wire to record former SA MP accused of blackmailing him, court documents state
node.description: SA Labor leader Peter Malinauskas was secretly fitted with a wire by detectives to record an interaction with former MP Annabel Digance and her husband who have since been accused of blackmail, according to court documents.

node.title: New $13 million price hike for Whangārei’s Oruku Landing conference and events centre
node.description: The controversial centre will now cost $136 million - up from $123 million when first announced at the start of public consultation on 18 October.

node.title: Napier residents criticise Covid-19 testing availability
node.description: Napier residents have criticised the "appalling communication and lack of action" from the local health board over Covid-19 testing.

node.title: Chip Shortage Creates New Power Players
node.description: Low-profile chip makers with aging factories have become surprisingly powerful, leading to industry changes that may outlive the pandemic-fueled supply crunch.

node.title: Retailers Scramble to Attract Workers Ahead of the Holidays
node.description: Signing bonuses, higher wages, even college tuition. Companies are using perks to entice new employees in an industry that has been battered by the pandemic.

node.title: Father of soldier killed in Afghanistan hits out at Defence for 'intimidation' and 'threats' toward families
node.description: The father of an Australian soldier murdered in Afghanistan claims families were threatened and intimidated by the Defence Department against speaking about details of the 2012 attack.

node.title: 'We’re all not the same': Former Don Dale detainees speak in support of $35 million class action
node.description: Lawyers are seeking more time to sign up hundreds of former youth justice detainees to the multi-million-dollar compensation claim, while a federal court takes time to consider if the settlement sum is fair and reasonable.

node.title: Astronomers catch over a third of all gravitational waves ever found in just five months
node.description: The addition of 35 new confirmed observations of these tiny ripples in the fabric of space time takes the tally to 90 detections since 2015.

node.title: Taranaki DHB has capacity to handle a Covid-19 outbreak - modelling
node.description: The Taranaki District Health Board has a Covid 'surge' plan in place that would enable it to cater for nine ventilated ICU patients and up to 60 in-patients.

node.title: Travis Scott, Astroworld organisers sued for at least $1 million as victims remembered
node.description: A clearer picture emerges of the eight victims who died at the Astroworld Festival during a crowd crush as one injured concertgoer sues rapper and event founder Travis Scott for $1 million in damages.

node.title: Despite drug law improvements, inequity remains for Māori, young people
node.description: New Zealand Drug Foundation Executive Director Sarah Helm says it is time to replace our outdated drug laws and replace them with a system

node.title: Study finds Aucklanders more likely than MIQ stayers to spread Covid-19
node.description: A group of public health experts say incoming travellers have a lower risk of carrying Covid-19 than the average Aucklander.

node.title: Bikie gang member charged over Nick Martin murder and attempted killing of two others
node.description: A second man is charged in connection with the sniper-style murder of Rebels bikie boss Nick Martin in Perth last year.

node.title: Child care provider fined after kids escape and almost run onto busy road
node.description: Dashcam footage captured the moment the toddlers were running along the busy Gold Coast street before a woman and school children came to their aid

node.title: 'We can no longer be friends': Farmer warns climate change deniers, after storm devastates crop
node.description: Storms have devastated more crops in South Australia's mid north, prompting a farmer to publicly declare he was cutting social ties with any climate change deniers.

node.title: Christchurch shooter flags appeal, claiming guilty pleas were made under duress
node.description: The Australian man convicted of killing 51 people in the attacks on two Christchurch mosques is claiming he experienced inhumane and degrading treatment while in custody.

node.title: COVID lockout restrictions extended in Greater Darwin amid concern about new exposure site
node.description: COVID lockout restrictions in Greater Darwin will be extended by an extra 24 hours after the identification of several new exposure sites, including one authorities have labelled of "particular concern", but the lockout in Katherine is on track to end at 5pm today.

node.title: Auckland farmers' markets wait for traffic light system before reopening
node.description: Two of Auckland's most popular farmers' markets will not be reopening next week, though they would be allowed to under level 3 step2.

node.title: Covid-19 update: 190 new community cases in New Zealand today
node.description: There have been 190 new community cases reported in New Zealand today, with 182 in Auckland, seven in Waikato and one in Northland.

node.title: What’s on TV This Week: Documentaries on Kevin Garnett and Jake Burton Carpenter
node.description: A pair of new documentaries, one on HBO and one on Showtime, look at two very different sports figures.

node.title: New data reveals how much protection COVID-19 jabs are giving people in NSW
node.description: People in NSW who are not vaccinated against COVID-19 were 16 times more likely to die, or end up in intensive care during the state's Delta outbreak, new government data reveals.

node.title: Country's oldest WWII veteran dies
node.description: New Zealand's oldest living World War II veteran, Bill Mitchell has died at 108 years old.

node.title: Why the ‘Scariest’ Night Didn’t Keep LaMarcus Aldridge Out of the N.B.A.
node.description: Aldridge, the veteran Nets center, briefly retired after 15 seasons because of a heart issue. He was depressed — then determined to return.

node.title: Your Monday Briefing
node.description: Rewriting China’s past.

node.title: Big Bird posted about getting his COVID vaccine. An American senator and anti-vax Twitter was having none of it
node.description: It started with a fairly innocent Twitter post shared by a beloved Sesame Street character. Then came the accusations of propaganda and brainwashing.

node.title: Time running out for 10-metre sperm whale stranded on Flinders Island
node.description: Conservation experts are attending to a sperm whale stranded off the coast of northern Tasmania — but an expert has warned the species are "not the easiest to refloat".

node.title: Port Beach unpatrolled at time of fatal shark attack, Health Minister reveals
node.description: WA Health Minister Roger Cook says the location of surf lifesaving patrols will be examined as beaches in the vicinity of this weekend's fatal shark attack reopen.

node.title: Three charged in connection with teen's death appear in court
node.description: Three people charged in connection with the death of a Christchurch teenager have appeared in court.

node.title: Daughter sentenced to 23 years for suffocating mother with a pillow
node.description: A West Australian woman who smothered her 71-year-old mother with a pillow in Tasmania and used her credit card to pay for a flight back home is sentenced to 23 years in prison.

node.title: Founding member of band UB40 dies at 64
node.description: British vocalist and founding member of UB40 Terence Wilson, better known by his stage name Astro, has died aged 64. Video

node.title: US citizen flown to Australia to make meth jailed over major bust in Adelaide drug house
node.description: An Iranian-born United States citizen who was found in his underwear hiding in the bedroom of a suburban Adelaide drug house is sentenced to at least five-and-a-half years in jail over an $18 million meth bust in 2018.

node.title: The rate of cancer cases in Victoria has dropped massively in the past two years, but experts say it's not good news
node.description: Health experts fear there are thousands of Australians who are unaware they have cancer due to COVID-19 lockdowns, with new data showing the number of detected cancer cases during the pandemic is way down.

node.title: As Flight Centre threatens a fresh hard border challenge, the WA government says it's 'up for the fight'
node.description: Western Australia's Health Minister Roger Cook says he is confident the state can fight another legal challenge against its hard border, as Flight Centre threatens a fresh court dispute.

node.title: ‘Insecure’ Season 5 Episode 3: Slow Start to Fatherhood
node.description: This week, Lawrence learns that fatherhood may not look like what he imagined.

node.title: Daughter found guilty of murdering mother after police find body and pillow
node.description: WA woman Natalie Maher is found guilty of murdering her mother in Tasmania before flying back home two days later using tickets paid for with her mother's credit card.

node.title: Schools could be kept open with 'test to stay' approach instead of quarantine, Doherty Institute says
node.description: A final report to government recommends using rapid antigen tests instead of quarantine for school children exposed to COVID-19 to safely limit the number of classroom teaching hours lost.

node.title: Police trying to establish if others involved in Cleo Smith abduction
node.description: Detectives say they expect to remain in Carnarvon for at least a week as they try to determine if more than one person was involved in Cleo Smith's abduction.

node.title: Indigenous culture to be celebrated as WBBL launches inaugural First Nations Round
node.description: The WBBL will hold its first league-wide First Nations Round this season, celebrating the hundreds of traditional custodians of the land that cricket is played on.

node.title: ‘Succession’ Recap, Season 3, Episode 4: Meep-Meep
node.description: After last week’s punishingly bleak episode, this week “Succession” brought some much-needed comic relief alongside the ongoing melodrama.

node.title: Booster shots are available from today — but check your calendar before you book
node.description: Australia's booster shot program is underway and hundreds of thousands of Australians can now get their third dose of the COVID-19 vaccine. Here's your guide to getting vaccinated (again).

node.title: The Astroworld crowd crush is not the first time safety at Travis Scott concerts has been questioned
node.description: Eight people are dead and many more injured following Travis Scott concert in Houston. But this is not the first time the rapper has been in trouble with the law over dangerous activity at his shows.

node.title: Somyurek admits to IBAC his electorate staff performed factional work
node.description: Disgraced former Victorian minister and Labor powerbroker Adem Somyurek admits to a corruption inquiry he hired factional operatives as his electorate staff and expected them to do some factional work.

node.title: 'Just a series of words': top UK advisor blasts Scott Morrison's climate speech
node.description: Lord Deben, chair of UK climate change advisory body, said it was disappointing that it appeared the Prime Minister didn't understand the urgency of climate change.

node.title: Specialists probe deaths of 4yo twins near Byron Bay as town grapples with 'unfathomable' loss
node.description: Police from the arson squad are travelling to Goonengerry after the sisters died on the weekend in a tragedy locals are describing as "incomprehensible".

node.title: 'The fair thing to do' - Govt to increase payments to struggling families
node.description: Almost 350,000 families will get an extra $20 a week from April next year, lifting 6000 more children out of poverty, Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern says.

node.title: Christchurch mosque terrorist claims inhumane treatment in prison
node.description: The Christchurch mosque terrorist says he pleaded guilty to the murder of 51 people last year because of the inhumane and degrading treatment he experienced while awaiting his trial.

node.title: Sydney Airport board agrees to $23.6bn takeover deal with international consortium
node.description: Australia's biggest and busiest airport could soon be changing hands, under a $23.6 billion takeover bid announced to the ASX this morning.

node.title: How No Time To Die could hint towards the next James Bond
node.description: The final James Bond film starring Daniel Craig as 007 comes out this week, ending one era and raising questions about where the franchise goes from here.

node.title: Trustpower reports solid profit gain on higher electricity generation
node.description: Trustpower's first half profit increased as it produced more power at higher prices, and gained from a rise in the value of its electricity hedges.

node.title: Linda Clark to head ACC client information and privacy review
node.description: The review follows the suspension of 14 ACC staff, after client information was shared and laughed at by ACC staff in a private Snapchat group.

node.title: Nurse who allegedly faked giving teenager COVID vaccine charged with fraud
node.description: A Perth nurse is arrested for vaccine fraud as police claim she pretended to give a teenager a COVID jab and then disposed of the dose, before allegedly falsifying the child's medical record.
